9.text:
It's great to join you all at Keele as our
hosts celebrate their 50th anniversary. Recalling

21.text:
the creation of universities back in the 1960s
reminds us of an optimistic sector in one

27.text:
of its most ambitious periods. Today, even
during this era of inevitable austerity, I

35.text:
believe that we can still be ambitious and
optimistic.

39.text:
The place of HE in the nation
2012 has certainly been a big year for Higher

42.text:
Education, with our reforms coming into effect.
I recognise that inevitably some stress and

49.text:
uncertainty accompanies changes on this scale.
The Government appreciates the maturity of

56.text:
the sector and the leadership of vice chancellors
in what are, for some, challenging times.

62.text:
In particular, I appreciate the Government's
close working relationship with UUK. We cannot

70.text:
always agree, but our discussions are always
open and founded on mutual trust. More than

78.text:
that, they are based on a shared belief that
our universities are a tremendous national

85.text: asset which we need to sustain and to grow.

92.text:
In popular consciousness, of course, 2012
will be remembered for the Olympics and Paralympics

103.text:
– which gave our universities some excellent
opportunities to demonstrate their place in

108.text:
national life. I congratulate UUK for illustrating
the many connections between universities

119.text:
and the Games. We all think especially of
Usain Bolt and his fellow Jamaican sprinters

126.text:
thanking their Birmingham University hosts
after capturing all the medals in the men's

132.text:
200 metres final. But there have also been
plenty of examples of volunteering and community

138.text:
engagement. We can all be proud of the university
research which improved the performance of

143.text:
our athletes and the university-designed equipment
which gave them a competitive edge. Now, the

150.text:
University of Worcester has launched a new
degree programme for those wanting to study

154.text: and ultimately work in disability sport.

158.text:
The debt of Olympians and Paralympians to
HE is just one example of a wider debt of

164.text:
many of us to our universities. Last week,
I was at the annual British science festival,

172.text:
sharing the excitement around the discovery
of the Higgs Boson and most recently the discovery

177.text:
that redundant DNA is not so redundant after
all. Again, British academics and universities

185.text:
are at the heart of these breakthroughs. With
your contributions to the intellectual life

190.text:
of our nation, to educating the next generation,
and to innovation and research, universities

197.text:
are more central to our society than ever
before.

201.text:
Protecting our national assets: cyber security
HE's growing economic importance was made

205.text:
plain at the recent launch of the Government's
cyber security guidance because quite simply,

213.text:
much of the UK's intellectual property resides
in our universities. Only this month, Oxford

225.text:
University confirmed that its online security
had been compromised by a cyber attack – just

229.text:
a day after the Cambridge University network
experienced disruption. The Government will

234.text:
work closely with universities to ensure that
the UK’s higher education system has a visible

241.text:
and credible international reputation for
protecting commercially sensitive research

247.text:
from the growing risks posed via cyber space.
But we can go further than just protection.

259.text:
Although UK universities are potential victims
of cyber attacks, they can also be a large

264.text:
part of the long term solution. GCHQ, the
EPSRC and BIS recently recognised eight UK

276.text:
universities as centres of academic excellence
in cyber security. There is real scope to

281.text:
translate this knowledge into commercial opportunities
and export earnings, while – for graduates

286.text:
– there are good prospects in cyber jobs
as demand increases, providing of course they

293.text:
Today I can announce the first academic research
institute – receiving total investment worth

299.text:
£3.8 million – to improve understanding
of the science behind cyber threats. This

306.text:
new facility, based at UCL, will draw on university
expertise in both technological and behavioural

313.text:
disciplines. Academic teams from UCL, Imperial,
Newcastle and Royal Holloway will be the first

319.text:
beneficiaries of research money. The institute
opens for business next month.

325.text:
Other kinds of "impact"
Clearly, part of the case for well-funded

328.text:
universities – as suggested by the example
of cyber security – is their economic benefit.

334.text:
But I readily acknowledge that this is not
what drives many academics, for whom intellectual

341.text:
curiosity is the main motive. It is a noble
motive, which must be respected. However,

349.text:
it does help when academics and universities
demonstrate how their research contributes

356.text:
to a strong economy and a good society. We
are supporting this crucial work.

362.text:
I can announce today that we are providing
an extra £6 million for the Higher Education

367.text:
Innovation Funding to be shared amongst a
number of universities to assist them in further

372.text:
driving growth, creating and supporting innovative
enterprises and building strategic relationships.

379.text:
The Research Excellence Framework will, for
the first time, recognise the highest levels

383.text:
of research excellence with reward for the
past impact that it has achieved. I know that

388.text:
you are currently busy preparing impact case
studies for the REF – and that you will

394.text:
all be aware of the breadth of “impact”
that this encompasses. It is not about “commercialisation”

402.text:
but more widely anything which has an effect
on, changes or benefits the economy, society,

409.text:
culture, public policy or services, health,
the environment or quality of life.

416.text:
The REF is an assessment of research excellence.
It is not about "journal rankings" or "journal

424.text:
impact factors". Whether the research output
has been published in an open access journal,

429.text:
a traditional publication, or even if it hasn't
been published in any journal at all, this

435.text:
does not affect the assessment of its quality
in the REF. REF panels will not make use of

441.text:
“journal impact factors”, rankings or
lists, nor the perceived standing of the publisher,

446.text:
in assessing the quality of research outputs.
An underpinning principle of the REF is that

453.text:
all types of research and all forms of research
output shall be assessed on a fair and equal

459.text: basis by experts in the relevant disciplines.

461.text:
Open access
As you know, we have also announced that we

464.text:
are shifting to open access for publicly funded
research published in these peer reviewed

470.text:
journals – following the excellent report
from Janet Finch, the former vice chancellor

474.text:
of this university. Removing pay walls will
have real economic and social benefits. Still,

481.text:
we understand that making the transition to
"gold" open access has a cost – roughly

486.text:
one per cent of the national science and research
budget.

491.text:
Last week I announced an extra £10 million
to be allocated to our 30 most research intensive

496.text:
universities to assist with the costs. This
is in addition to the contribution RCUK will

501.text:
be making to institutions to support payment
of article processing charges associated with

507.text:
open access, through block funding grants
from next April onwards. We'll be providing

512.text:
more detail on this soon, and the UK Funding
Councils will launch a consultation on setting

518.text:
a requirement that research outputs submitted
to any REF should be as widely accessible

525.text:
HE and philanthropy
Another report, published only yesterday by

528.text:
HEFCE, I particularly commend to you. I took
Professor Shirley Pearce's excellent Review

535.text:
of Philanthropy in UK Higher Education on
holiday with me, and very much enjoyed reading

543.text:
There has been substantial momentum since
Eric Thomas’s excellent 2004 report. The

550.text:
matched funding pot has meant that many more
universities and colleges have been able to

554.text:
attract philanthropic gifts over recent years,
and voluntary giving has improved across the

560.text:
In these financially strapped times a challenge
for every institution is to diversify its

564.text:
income streams and develop strategies to stimulate
donations– to position their institution

570.text:
as an attractive proposition. Both BIS and
HEFCE will be giving the report’s recommendations

575.text:
serious attention. Shirley and her team have
made many telling observations, including

580.text:
on donor behaviour. We will be guided on your
views. We do need to remind people of the

586.text:
charitable status of many university activities.
If the option of a charity number for a university

592.text:
would help, we can take it up with the Charity
Commission. And it is right philanthropy is

597.text:
properly recognised in honours system, so
do put people forward to us and the Cabinet

606.text:
The new fees regime
Now, this is the month when the first students

611.text:
will arrive at university under the new fees
regime. I believe the financing changes, despite

618.text:
the controversy, are in the best interests
of universities, students, and the nation.

625.text:
As the Institute of Fiscal Studies concluded
over the summer, the new regime is "substantially

630.text:
more progressive" than the previous system
– with the poorest 30 per cent of graduates

636.text:
set to pay back less over their lifetimes.
The IFS noted that universities will receive

642.text:
more money to invest in education, while taxpayers
will save around £2,500 per graduate. And

651.text:
we are proud of the extra financial support
for part-time students.

657.text:
So, in constrained circumstances the reforms
achieve three crucial objectives.

665.text:
First we have saved money for the Exchequer
without reducing the cash flowing to our universities.

671.text:
In 2011-12, the sum of teaching grant and
student loan money reaching institutions was

679.text:
£7.2 billion. In 2012-13, it is £7.4 billion.
The indicative figure for 2013-14 is £7.9

691.text:
billion. That is not bad in these austere
times.

696.text:
Second, there is more competition and choice
for the benefit of students. Under the new

702.text:
funding system, students still receive public
funding. We have to predict and control this

707.text:
cost, so – like every previous government
– we have to maintain student number controls.

712.text:
But we favour relaxing these controls for
individual universities within an overall

716.text:
total, so that more students can go to whichever
university wants to accept them. We favour

721.text:
maximum possible choice for students, to accommodate
for example those who may want to study locally,

726.text:
and those who may want to choose an institution
offering lower tuition charges. We are moving

731.text:
from a world in which each institution is
allocated a fixed number of students to what

735.text: is indeed a more open and competitive system.

740.text:
As you know, the AAB and core/margin policies
seek to move towards those objectives, within

746.text:
the fiscal constraints we face. We asked HEFCE
to implement them, including making the best

752.text:
assumptions they could about numbers. In order
to set the necessary rules in a competitive

758.text:
system, the assumptions had to be fixed in
advance.

761.text:
It is still too early to know fully what the
outcome has been, and how students are responding.

768.text:
It looks as if there may have been fewer pupils
achieving predicted AAB grades at "A" level,

775.text:
but rather more getting top grades in equivalent
high-class vocational qualifications, such

781.text:
as BTECs. The net result may be total numbers
getting AAB or equivalent which are closer

788.text:
to 80,000 than to 85,000, which was HEFCE's
best estimate. Different institutions will

795.text:
have been affected differently; that is inevitable
when making significant changes, which are

800.text:
intended to take greater account of student
choice. I recognise this comes at a time when

806.text:
there have been other pressures too. The number
of 18 year olds is falling. Demand is unusually

812.text:
depressed this year because more students
went straight to university last year, missing

817.text:
out a gap year. And more may be delaying until
next year when ABB kicks in. The evidence

825.text:
from the Labour government’s changes in
2006 is that individual institutions can face

830.text:
a temporary jolt when changes like this are
introduced. All this creates real pressures

836.text:
for some institutions. But HEFCE will take
this year's outcomes into account as it implements

845.text:
the changes we announced for 13/14, in the
shape of a move to ABB or equivalent, plus

856.text:
The third objective to which the reforms contribute
is the greater information becoming available

860.text:
to prospective students – what I consider
to be the final piece in the jigsaw. The Which

872.text:
guide has only just gone live, and I was pleased
to attend the launch. Later this month we

878.text:
will be launching new Key Information Set
data – which will also be available on university

888.text:
websites and on the updated Unistats site,
enabling comparisons among institutions. The

894.text:
key indicators and summary information for
students are unquestionably a force for good,

900.text:
but they are certainly not perfect and we
should strive to improve them. HEFCE will

904.text:
carry out a comprehensive review of the student
information landscape starting next year.

910.text:
A revolution in teaching
Add all this together and we're looking at

913.text:
what amounts to a revolution in teaching – the
largest cultural change in our universities

919.text:
for a generation. Research has been the primary
focus of attention for a long time; it's time

925.text:
for teaching to be in the spotlight as well.
In 2010 two important reports were published

933.text:
– not just Lord Browne's but also Graham
Gibbs's conclusions on how to measure teaching

939.text:
quality. It's also worth remembering, as we
approach the 50th anniversary of the Robbins

945.text:
report, that Robbins himself was preoccupied
with teaching quality. I met Claus Moser earlier

952.text:
this year, one of Robbins's key researchers
alongside Richard Layard, and he confirmed

957.text: that teaching was uppermost in their minds.

960.text:
Keele, of course, put heavy store by teaching
from the very beginning. Indeed, the 1964

965.text:
Hale report on "University Teaching Methods"
found that it was, at one time, the only institution

971.text:
with a Research Fellow on university teaching.
I am also glad to acknowledge that the NUS,

976.text:
whose 90th anniversary we marked last night,
has long campaigned about the quality of teaching.

985.text:
Now universities really do need to focus on
the excellence of their teaching. At the end

989.text:
of this new term there will be many students
returning home whose parents will be asking

996.text:
what they got for £3000. How crowded were
the seminars? What were the labs like? How

1003.text:
many essays did you write? How much academic
feedback did you get? Every university in

1009.text:
this room needs to be confident your students
will have good answers to those questions.

1015.text:
An environment that focuses on engaging students
in their academic study means that those students

1020.text:
are continually encouraged to apply themselves.
I hope that applicants will make full use

1025.text:
of the KIS data in figuring out which institutions
can offer the most appropriate teaching environment

1031.text:
for their individual needs – and that universities
will adjust to student- and parent-power.

1035.text:
Student numbers
Robbins, of course, is most associated with

1039.text:
expansion of the sector, even though that
was partly set in train before he reported,

1044.text:
as Keele perfectly illustrates. Perhaps we
can best view the history of our HE sector

1069.text:
as successive waves of expansion – a progressive
interpretation that I welcome. There are periods

1076.text:
between the waves where consolidation is the
order of the day – like the current one

1080.text:
where the number of 18-year-olds is in decline
– making the raw UCAS application figures

1085.text:
somewhat misleading. However, I believe that
more growth will come and universities can

1091.text:
rise to the challenge of proving Kingsley
Amis wrong in his sour prognostication that

1101.text:
Indeed various surveys show that the number
of young people aspiring to go to university

1105.text:
has increased steadily over the past 10 years.
The most recent Sutton Trust survey, published

1110.text:
in April this year, encouragingly showed that
around three quarters of year 10 to 12 pupils

1116.text:
were likely to apply to university with a
similar proportion of those in year 13 actually

1122.text:
applying. According to the Millennium cohort
study, 97 per cent of mothers want their children

1127.text:
to go to university. I'm also very encouraged
by the evidence that increased fees are not

1133.text:
putting off young people from poor backgrounds
– with a recorded fall of just 0.2 per cent.

1138.text:
Improving access
All the more reason to welcome Les Ebdon,

1142.text:
who has now started work as the Director of
Fair Access. OFFA has additional resources

1148.text:
to support as well as challenge institutions.
Vince Cable and I wrote to HEFCE and OFFA

1154.text:
in May, asking them to develop a shared strategy
for promoting access which maximises the impact

1159.text: of all spending by Government, HEFCE and institutions.

1163.text:
There is so much going on now that it is right
to assess what works best to widen participation

1169.text:
and broaden access, taking into account the
latest available evidence here and abroad.

1174.text:
The Government believes it is right for institutions
to seek to broaden access because real meritocracy

1180.text:
means making sure talent is spotted, not wasted.
Individuals must be considered on their merits,

1187.text:
and institutions’ procedures must be, as
we say in the White Paper, “fair, transparent

1192.text:
and evidence-based”. And we all understand
the Director’s duty to protect academic

1197.text:
freedom, including an institution’s right
to decide who to admit and on what basis.

1202.text:
New providers & VAT
As the HE sector grows it needs to continue

1206.text:
to be open to new types of provider. It always
has been. Represented here today are universities

1214.text:
that can trace their origins back to ancient
foundations, mechanics institutes, Anglican

1221.text:
teaching colleges, Colleges of Advanced Technology
– all of which took a different route to

1227.text:
university status. This year we have eased
number limits and I hope as a result we will

1232.text:
see at least 10 smaller institutions calling
themselves universities for the first time

1237.text:
– including alternative providers, so long
as they are of the necessary standard.

1243.text:
Yesterday, HMRC published a consultation on
extending the VAT exemption to for-profit

1249.text:
providers of HE. Currently, the majority of
these providers cannot benefit from this exemption

1255.text:
in the same way that not-for profit providers
can. This potentially puts them at a competitive

1260.text:
disadvantage in the market and runs counter
to our vision of a more level playing field

1266.text:
for all. I welcome this opportunity to review
such treatment.

1269.text:
Industrial strategy and education exports
When Vince Cable launched our industrial strategy

1273.text:
on Tuesday, we identified education as one
of the key sectors of the future. Our universities,

1280.text:
for one, are internationally recognised. We
can do more to take advantage of our position.

1287.text:
You are a great British export industry, and
in a growing market – in 2000 there were

1295.text:
just over 2 million students worldwide studying
outside their own countries. Ten years later

1302.text:
this had doubled to 4 million. By 2020 it
is predicted to be around 7 million. Our education

1311.text:
exports are already worth around £14 billion,
and could rise to around £20 billion in 2020

1317.text:
and nearly £27 billion in 2025, representing
an annual growth rate of approximately 5 per

1325.text:
Some of our key economic partners of the future
like Turkey, Indonesia, Brazil are experiencing

1332.text:
a surge in the number of young people. They
are keen to invest in this generation through

1337.text:
more HE at home and more opportunities abroad.
That is why HE now has such an important role

1344.text:
in our trade missions. Earlier this year,
vice chancellors accompanied the PM and me

1349.text:
to Asia. We're going to Brazil later this
month.

1353.text:
Opportunities for UK education overseas extend
significantly beyond teaching students. For

1358.text:
example, other countries are attracted to
the expertise that UK institutions can offer

1362.text:
in governance models, professional development
and curricular design; construction, management

1368.text:
and financing. Some foreign education systems,
particularly in emerging markets, have complex

1375.text:
needs. For them, we are adopting a new approach,
which we are calling "system-to-system" – facilitated

1383.text:
and coordinated by the UK Government. Under
this umbrella, the new UK Education Services

1389.text:
will identify opportunities, then initiate
and mobilise consortia to win the contracts.

1395.text:
It could include higher education, further
education and schools, as well as a range

1399.text:
of non-education specific services. I am taking
a delegation on a system-to-system education

1406.text:
export mission to Colombia and Mexico later
this year.

1410.text:
The system-to-system approach is not about
replacing or duplicating the many excellent

1415.text:
initiatives underway. But system-to-system
supplements the bilateral opportunities already

1421.text:
undertaken by many institutions 
and other organisations.

1437.text:
Overseas students travelling to the UK to
study is just one way we can grow. Last year

1443.text:
400,000 overseas students came to the UK to
study. But for the first time this was exceeded

1447.text:
by the record 500,000 people who benefitted
from British higher education while living

1453.text:
abroad. I salute the trail blazers like Nottingham,
Liverpool Reading, UCL and Newcastle with

1459.text:
campuses abroad. On a recent visit to the
US I was struck by the surge of activity in

1467.text:
distance learning. We may be at a tipping
point in distance learning as technology offers

1472.text:
more efficient and more effective ways of
online learning than ever before. We will

1477.text:
be doing more work on this in BIS over the
months ahead as I believe these forms of education

1482.text: are really going to take off.

1484.text:
Visas and the situation at London Met
There are few sectors of our economy with

1488.text:
the capacity to grow and generate export earnings
as great as higher education. Every overseas

1494.text:
student on average pays fees of about £10,000
a year and spends almost as much while they

1502.text:
are here. That means 400,000 overseas students
bring in almost £8 billion a year. They make

1509.text:
a big contribution to the economies of cities
like Bradford and Exeter and Manchester, as

1518.text:
We must not allow the London Met issues to
jeopardise this success story. I am grateful

1524.text:
to the whole sector for its prompt, coordinated
and effective response to the UKBA’s decision

1532.text:
to remove London Met’s tier 4 sponsor licence.
Both UUK and the NUS are playing a full role

1541.text:
in the London Met task force that I set up
within hours UKBA’s announcement. Individual

1547.text:
universities are offering places for the mini
clearing operation that goes live next Monday.

1554.text:
We must not lose sight of the individual students
who are most affected by the current situation

1561.text:
and we must maintain confidence across the
world in the fair deal for overseas students.

1569.text:
They may face costs of moving to alternative
accommodation and costs of applying for a

1574.text:
new visa. So I can announce today that we
are setting up a £2 million fund to help

1580.text:
legitimate overseas students at London Met
who face extra costs through no fault of their

1587.text:
own as a result of transferring to another
institution. This will provide certainty to

1593.text:
London Met students at what is a stressful
and unsettling time.

1599.text:
I hope no other institution will face a similar
situation in future. But it makes sense for

1604.text:
the sector to plan now for how it would manage
that risk if it did arise – we need to underline

1611.text:
the message to students and potential students
and their families that the UK is a safe and

1616.text:
welcoming destination. There are examples
of protection schemes in other countries and

1620.text:
in other sectors – the ABTA scheme is one
obvious example. So I very much welcome UUK's

1625.text:
willingness to develop proposals for a sector-led
response to discuss with all its members.

1630.text:
I look forward to seeing the results of that
work.

1634.text:
We must go further to protect our international
reputation in the short-term too. We have

1639.text:
already used Foreign Office posts to signal
that we remain open to overseas students and

1644.text:
I have agreed with your President, Eric Thomas,
that we will jointly author an article to

1650.text:
offer to key newspapers in our target markets
explaining that overseas students are welcome

1656.text:
here, and reminding them of what a great opportunity
it is to study in UK.

1663.text:
Every year, countries around the world send
their best and brightest here to learn. When

1667.text:
they come, they bring with them the potential
to add a rich and diverse cultural scene to

1672.text:
many of our towns and cities. They bring a
great opportunity to make our courses more

1677.text:
international in scope and to contribute to
enabling a well-rounded education for our

1681.text:
home students. This is a globalised world,
and our people should consider themselves

1687.text:
privileged to be exposed to such talented
people from all its corners. Without international

1693.text:
students, we would not only be poorer economically
– we would also be more boring, more insular,

1699.text: and more ignorant of the wider world.

1701.text:
That is why transparency in the immigration
statistics is vital. We therefore want to

1707.text:
publicise disaggregated figures so that the
debate can be better informed. The ONS is

1713.text:
planning improvements in its methodology so
that in future it will be possible to better

1719.text: identify students in the emigration flows.

1724.text:
I want to make clear the attitude of the government.
There is no limit on the number of legitimate

1730.text:
students from overseas studying at British
universities. They have to have the language

1736.text:
skills and the academic training to benefit
from Higher Education here. It is in everyone’s

1742.text:
interest to maintain our high standards. The
vast majority of international students are

1747.text:
here legitimately, study hard, contribute
to our economy, and take nothing from us except

1752.text:
a world-class education. Where things are
working at their best, they also make us more

1757.text:
cosmopolitan, sustain links between our communities
with heritage in other parts of the world

1762.text:
and those places, and make the higher education
offer more diverse than it otherwise would

1766.text:
be. It is crucial that we sustain and develop
these advantages.

1771.text:
Conclusion…
The Coalition believes in our great higher

1774.text:
education institutions. Whenever David Cameron
is listing our great national assets, he puts

1779.text:
our universities high on the list. We are
proud of our international reputation. We

1784.text:
are proud so many students from around the
world want to come and study here. We are

1788.text:
proud that the lives of so many British people
are transformed by the opportunity to study

1793.text:
at our great universities. And everything
we know about our culture, the needs of our

1798.text:
economy, and the aspirations of our young
people tells us that our universities will

1804.text: have an even greater role in the future.
